newsitem.title: CANADA: Economic growth to help corporate Canada's Q4.
newsitem.headline: Economic growth to help corporate Canada's Q4.

text.p: Canada's robust economic growth in recent months will likely provide some pleasant surprises for investors when fourth-quarter Canadian corporate earnings roll out over the next few weeks.

Optimism about earnings is helping the bull market in Canada keep charging ahead. But analysts said blighted natural resource companies -- with the notable exception of oil and gas producers -- would probably post poor results in contrast with other business sectors.
"I think you're going to see surprising numbers on the upside right across the board. And I say that coming from a macro (economic) view," predicted Bob Boaz, a market strategist at HSBC James Capel.

"The way the economy has been performing, it's been surprising a lot of people through the fourth quarter...the trade balance in Canada has been moving ahead by leaps and bounds and that normally translates into good profitability," he added.

Industrial products companies were expected to beat analysts' forecasts, particularly those firms that export a lot of their output south of the border, said Jim Doak, senior vice-president, investment research, at brokerage ScotiaMcLeod Inc.

"(Industrial products) should be solid. The export numbers that we have been seeing have been good, so that implies that the exports of manufactured goods remain intact," noted Dunnery Best, director of private client investing at Midland brokerage Walwyn Inc.

Boaz said industrial products concerns likely to deliver solid earnings advances included Unican Security Systems Ltd., Premdor Inc., Skyjack Inc., Spar Aerospace Ltd., Northern Telecom Ltd. and Newbridge Networks Corp..

While fourth-quarter economic data have not yet been released, economists polled in a Reuters survey forecast that Canada's merchandise trade balance would show a surplus of C$2.92 billion ($2.18 billion) in November, compared to C$1.49 billion ($1.12 billion) in October. The official data are due out Friday.
Real estate and energy were among other sectors that would likely turn in a good quarterly performance, analysts said.
The once-moribund real estate group has heated up recently as Canada's bargain-basement interest rates boost occupancy and lease rates in the industrial, office and retail areas.
Oil and gas producers should benefit from the recent gusher in crude oil and gas prices, making them an exception in the natural resource world.

"I think a lot of the resource companies will do relatively poorly, with the exception of the energy sector. Metals, forest products, I think are going to report a very bad fourth quarter," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer and Co.
"(Oil and gas) I think should show a very strong fourth quarter. And I expect prices to remain firm and to actually edge up in 1997 and refining margins also will improve," he added.
Metz said the tail-end of 1996 and the beginning of 1997 could mark a low for many commodity prices, which, he believed, could turn sharply upward during the year.
Most analysts reckon forest products and mining companies had a tough time eking out profits for the fourth quarter and for 1996 as a whole.
But many major gold producers hedged, or sold forward, much of their production, which should offset the impact of the slide in world bullion prices and help cushion earnings.
